column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=4. Discussion
#Text=4.1. Perception of Safety
#Text=Our survey showed that respondents generally felt less safe while walking around dockless e-scooters than they were around the different types of bicycles .
#Text=We found a similar result for driving around e-scooters .
#Text=Increased discomfort around e-scooters may be explained by e-scooters being a new mode that pedestrians ( and drivers ) are not yet used to .

#Text=For drivers , previous research has found that motorists fail to notice motorcycles at a higher rate than automobiles , likely due to drivers not expecting to see motorcycles , making it difficult to notice them .
#Text=This phenomenon has been used to explain the inverse correlation between the number of bicyclists and pedestrians and the rate of cyclist and pedestrian crashes .

#Text=Researchers have found that , as cyclists and pedestrian numbers increase , safety increases , known as the ‘ safety in numbers effect , ’ which could be explained by drivers becoming more acclimated to seeing cyclists on the road .
#Text=E-scooters , unlike bicycles and motorcycles , are a new mode of transport , and both riders and drivers are not yet used to how they operate in traffic .
#Text=The survey also reveals large differences in comfort and perceived safety between those who had used dockless e-scooters before and those who had not .
#Text=More than three quarters ( 76 % ) of non-riders reported feeling “ unsafe ” or “ very unsafe ” walking around dockless e-scooters while only one quarter ( 24 % ) of riders felt this way .
#Text=This could be explained by riders having a greater familiarity with the devices than those who had never ridden them before .
#Text=A similar difference appeared when respondents were asked to report how frequently they encountered a sidewalk blocked by a dockless e-scooter .
#Text=One-third of non-riders reported “ always ” encountering blocked sidewalks while only 7 % of riders reported “ always ” encountering them .
#Text=These results are similar toa Washington , DC survey that found that 80 % of respondents who did not approve of the city allowing e-scooters to operate had never tried the service ( p.34 ) .

#Text=While these differences could indicate that greater familiarity with dockless e-scooters leads people to be less bothered by them and to feel safer around them , causation is hard to determine .
#Text=It could also be the case that people who do not like dockless e-scooters and feel uncomfortable around them choose not to use them .
#Text=In our survey , those who had used dockless e-scooters before were , on average , much younger than those who had not ( 84 % of riders were younger than 34 compared to 45 % of non-riders ) .
#Text=This age difference may matter .
#Text=An e-scooter on the sidewalk might pose a greater challenge to older individuals who may not be able to move the e-scooter out of the way or walk around it as easily as younger respondents .
#Text=Moreover , our study did not define what a “ blocked ” sidewalk was , nor did we quantify the frequency terms we offered ( e.g. “ always ” ) .
#Text=Thus , our respondents likely had different ideas about what constitutes a blocked sidewalk when responding to our question .
#Text=Similarly , it is possible that someone who has experience with using the devices or is able to step over or move them out of the way

#Text=does not notice how often they have to do so ; while , conversely , someone who has more trouble with them may notice it more , so that the same number of encounters may seem “ frequent ” or “ infrequent ” to different people .
#Text=We recommend that future studies ask more specifically about the number of instances of blocked sidewalks rather than reporting on the categories we used .
#Text=4.2. Knowledge of Laws
#Text=Respondents , even those who had used dockless e-scooters before , were generally unfamiliar with local e-scooter laws .

#Text=In Arlington County , e-scooters are not allowed to be ridden on the sidewalk or trails , e-bikes are allowed to be ridden on sidewalks but not trails , and riders of bikes and e-scooters are not required to wear helmets .
#Text=Of note , 43 % of respondents who had used a dockless e-scooter in Rosslyn reported that they did not know what the laws governing dockless vehicles in Arlington County were .
#Text=This is a much higher percentage than a similar survey of e-scooter riders in Portland , OR found .
#Text=In that survey , 26 % of e-scooter riders said they were unfamiliar with e-scooter laws .

#Text=Portland e-scooter riders were also better at correctly identifying laws ; 59 % of Rosslyn e-scooter riders thought that riders were required to wear helmets even though Arlington does not require helmet use .

#Text=In Portland , which requires riders to wear helmets , 67 % of e-scooter riders correctly said that helmet use was required , while 65 % of Portland riders correctly said that e-scooters were not allowed to be ridden on the sidewalk compared to only 57 % of Rosslyn e-scooter riders .
